captions.text:
Hi, I'm Dr. Katy Nelson
for Iams with Howdini.

Today we're going to talk about
dog nutrition and what

you should look for in
your puppy's food.

Just like infants, puppies
require different levels of
nutrients than older dogs.

Physically puppies grow
fastest during
the first six months.

The right nutrition
is critical to
support this rapid growth.

That said, your puppy should
only receive premium puppy

food until he reaches his
adult height and weight.

That's typically in the first
year for small and medium

breeds and can be up
to two years for
large and giant breeds.

One more thing to consider
is that a puppy's energy

requirements can be nearly twice
that of an adult dog.

And since their stomachs are
smaller they need more

nutritionally dense food
formulated just for puppies to

help them meet their
energy needs.
There are three types of food.
Dry kibble.

Semi-moist, which comes
in sealed packages.
And moist, or canned.

Most veterinarians and trainers
recommend dry kibble

food because of its fat content
and the fact that
moist food can spoil.

Dry kibble also helps with
tartar control which is

particularly important for
his developing teeth.

When you're shopping for food,
there a couple of things you

want to look for and
keep in mind.

Number one, look on the label
for a statement that says

formulated to meet the
nutritional levels established

by the AAFCO dog food Nutrient
Profiles for Growth.

Number two, read the ingredients
list on the back

of the package and look for
real meat as the first
ingredient.

Puppies grow the fastest
during the first
six months of life.

And because growth rates differ
among breed sizes, you

need to feed a formula designed
to address the needs

of your puppy's breed
and size.

Ideally, puppy food should
also contain animal-based
protein for strong muscles.

The protein requirement for
growing poppies is higher than
that for adult dogs.

High quality protein is critical
for puppies to create
new body tissue as they grow.

Calcium for strong
bones and teeth.
Iron for healthy blood.

DHA for the brain, central
nervous system, and vision.

DHA is a key ingredient found
naturally in mother's milk and

is important for a baby's
neural development.

Just like a baby, your puppy's
ability to learn depends on
healthy brain development.

Probiotics for a healthy immune
system, because 65% of

your puppy's immune system is
in its digestive tract.

And high in calories for all
the energy a puppy burns.

The nutritional needs for
puppies differ for different
breeds sizes.

Large breed puppies
grow more quickly.

Because of that, they actually
need less calcium so their

bones don't grow too fast.
Medium breed dogs need a

careful balance of calories and
nutrients to be sure that
they don't gain excess weight.

While small breed puppies need
nutrient dense food in small

bites because their metabolism
tends to be faster.

and they have different energy
needs than larger dogs.

Another important thing to know
is that what is good for

humans is not necessarily
good for animals.

Because proper nutrition
is critical for optimal

development, and because human
food doesn't offer the proper

balance of nutrients puppies
need, it is important teach

your whole family that feeding
your puppy or your dog table

scraps is a big no-no and
a major health hazard.

Now let's talk about
feeding schedules.

Just like babies, puppies do
best on a regular schedule.

Schedules teach them that there
are times to eat, times
to play, and times to potty.

Obviously the feeding schedule
will largely be dictated by
your own personal schedule.

But no matter what, it is
critical that puppies younger

than four months be feed
multiple times per day.

Depending on your puppies
breed size at around six

months you can start to limit
feelings to twice a day.

Also keep in mind that eating
is soon followed by the urge
to go to the bathroom.

If you work away from your house
and are unable to feed

and walk your puppy as often as
needed, think hiring a dog

walker or ask a neighbor to help
you keep your puppy on
his schedule.

For more information on house
training, watch "How to house
train your puppy."

Another important nutritional
determinant is how much you

were supposed to feed your
developing puppy.

Even though the back of the
puppy food bags usually have

suggested portion sizes based on
weight, they are not always
right for your puppy.

So it's best to pay attention to
your puppy's body and talk
to your veterinarian.

Remember a fat puppy is not
necessarily a healthy puppy.

Just as childhood obesity can
lead to adult health issues in

humans, monitoring a puppy's
weight is very important to
ensure proper development.

Treats are another food source
to consider when determining
portion size.

It is important to limit
treating to less than 10% of

your puppy's daily
caloric intake.

When selecting treats, hard chew
treats are ideal because

they improve dental health
through gnawing.

Also try to save treating for
training sessions to reward

good behavior, but be careful
not to overdo it.

For more information on
training, watch our video
"Puppy training basics."

The last part of puppy nutrition
we are going to talk
about is water.

Puppies need fresh, clean water
available at all times.

Like us, is their most
important nutrient.

You should change your puppy's
water often, at
least once a day.

Providing fresh, clean water
greatly reduces the risk of

disease, and therefore keeps
your pet happy and healthy.

I'm Dr. Katy Nelson for
Iams with Howdini.

And I hope that you found this
helpful as you welcome your
new addition into your family.

For more information on puppy
care and training, visit
iams.com/puppy.

title: How To Feed a Puppy - How To Choose the Best Puppy Food

yes you can and should definitely feed your dog raw meat. start with

comments.text:
Regular tap water is fine for NO ONE. Does your city fluoridate their water 
supply? There are many chemicals and additives in most water supplies. I do 
not give my dog tap water, never did and never will. I give spring water, 
this is less apt to have fluoride among other things. Look into it for 
yourself...
comments.author: toriinprogress

comments.text:
Remember people: DO YOUR OWN RESEARCH!!! People try to sell things everyday 
and most buy without thinking twice. Think for yourself...more importantly 
(if you're here) for your dog :) I've recently acquired a new pup and more 
than likely once he is free of worms and has a clean bill of health, I will 
go back to home cooking as I did with my last dog. What do you think folks 
did back in the day before commercialized pet foods were available? There 
are bad, bad things in pet food...
comments.author: toriinprogress

comments.text:
Absolutely. This is the best way to feed your dogs/puppies but there is a 
lot of research involved to make sure you're giving your dog/pup all the 
nutrition it needs as it needs a balanced diet too. It will need veggies 
and grains as well. I cooked regularly for my last dog. 60%protein, 
25%veggies & 15%grains but that was due to her cancer. You'll need to look 
into what % is right for a growing pup!!! This is a lot of work but you're 
dog can eat with you :) Salmon, broccoli & rice for example.
comments.author: toriinprogress

comments.author: MrF0R3V3RCANAD1AN

comments.text:
Yes! A raw natural diet is the best for dogs- it's what they evolved to eat 
and my dog is living proof- immaculate teeth, shiny coat, small stools- he 
gets raw meat, eggs, fish, tripe, offal and edible bones like lamb ribs. My 
vet is pro raw as are many others in the UK. Most people that say no to raw 
just don't know what encompasses a balanced raw diet. NEVER feed cooked 
bone.
comments.author: Claire Morgan

comments.text:
Regular tap water should be fine unless you have extremely high mineral 
deposits in your city water. Basically, if you can drink it then it is 
fine. That only goes for water. Do not offer milk, soda, juice, alcohol 
etc.
comments.author: Howdini

what kind of water should i be feeding my pup, should i get bottled water 
or dish water, and is milk good too?
comments.author: Jason You

comments.text:
Yes. Best for their dental health is to only do dry food. Maltese's are a 
breed that will need regular dental cleanings and keeping her on the dry 
will help prolong the need for professional dental cleanings. She may 
resist it at first but hang on tight. They LOVE wet food but NEED dry.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
The earlier in the day the better. Your puppy is still young and adjusting 
to your home. She will eventually outgrow these late at night potty trips. 
Also, keep in mind that the VERY LAST THING you do before you go to bed is 
let her out. 7pm is very early for her to have her last potty break. If you 
go to be at 11pm then she NEEDS to go out at 10:59pm. KWIM?
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: All of our pets are rescues so their true lineage is unknown.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
At about 1 year old is when they are old enough to go on a Maintenance 
diet. A good adult food is now in order. Keep in mind that is you have a 
small breed that smaller kibble is best. If you have a VERY active dog, 
then a Performance formula is in order. If you have an obese dog, then 
weight management formulas are best.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text: And also should I cut out wet food and feed my puppy only dry food?

comments.text:

too? I am sure that you are feeding him enough regular food but you may 
want to make sure that he is still not hungry after he is done eating.

comments.text:
Oh yes...that is a tough one (and nasty!) You have to keep working with him 
on this one. I'm sure you clean up his mess as soon as you see it, but that 
is really the key.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
check with your vet since he/she is physically in contact with your dog. 
He/she will be monitoring his growth and weight at each visit and can 
really tailor a feeding schedule that is perfectly suited for your dog. :)
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
You really need to ask your vet b/c 4 weeks is WAY too young to be taken 
from its mother. Seeking the advice from your vet will guide to the 
healthiest way to safely care for him.

comments.text:
For most areas, barring any hazardous environmental issues, tap water 
should be fine.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
Every puppy is going to have its preferences. You may want to start off 
with what the breeder sent home with you...then ask your vet what he/she 
would recommend and why.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.author: Kai Zhai

comments.text: How old is your dog? What breed is he? Some breeds do this naturally.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
You really need to stick to a puppy formulated diet. If he does not like 
the one you are giving him try a different one. Since he is SO young you 
may want to try a moist/wet food for a few day mixed with the crunchy so he 
can adjust.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
i feed my 2month old pom with pedigree. i've been mixing them with milk as 
he doesn't want to eat it. my vet said, it's because i had let him taste 
table food (not left overs, ok?) when he first came to our house. now, im 
having a hard time feeding him. :-( any suggestion? im worried because now 
he's less active. please.........
comments.author: graceasia

comments.text:
5 week old puppies still need to be nursed by their mothers. 8 weeks is 
about the average age to transition them to puppy food. We do not recommend 
raw food. Puppy food is formulated w/ higher amounts of protein and fat 
balanced w/ fiber and other grains to meet the needs of growing puppies.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
it is a very informative video but i have a doubt... i have a 5 week old 
German shepherd isn't raw food the best for a puppy..? and how and when 
should try and bring him to raw food.. and what recipies and procedures 
would u recommend..?
comments.author: Jaspreet Singh Kalra

comments.text:
You should first check with your vet and see what he/she recommend. 
However, generally speaking there are differences between "grocery store" 
brands and "premium" brands. Check the ingredients. Your really want one 
that has REAL FOOD as the 1st three ingredients. Ie. Chicken, Beef, Veal 
etc. There is a big price difference to keep in mind. Most vets would 
recommend only feeding dry kibble to keep the teeth as healthy as possible.
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
i feed my 10 week old puppy pedigree can in jelly puppy food (chicken and 
rice) is that okay for a samoyed puppy???
comments.author: elle davis

comments.text:
You won't know what he will like until you have him try it. Maybe your vet 
or local pet store have some samples for you to try. Also, if you email and 
contact manufactures directly, they are usually willing to send you samples 
to try. Keep in mind that most pet store offer a money back guarantee. So, 
if he does not eat what you have bought you can exchange it. Have you taken 
him to the vet to make sure that there is not a "medical" reason why he is 
not eating? You want to make sure he is healthy
comments.author: Howdini

comments.text:
i have a 12 week staffishire he is a reall fussie eater and will some times 
not eat his food for 1 day at a time ive tryed all differnt kind in case 
itis the make he doesnt like. how do i no what to buy him thanks
comments.author: Donna Mcintyre
